slidelink.displaytext: Anger & Disrespect in the Write Room
Students Being Disrespectful to Each Other

search.slidetext: dealing with difficult tutoring situations: managing student behavior a crla level 2 training module developed by the learning assistance center, howard community college this presentation has audio click next to continue click menu to jump to a specific slide

objectives identify strategies to address types of behaviors that can create challenges or problems in tutoring sessions. determine how difficult behaviors can impact you and your tutees. examine real-life scenarios lac tutors have experienced and discuss tips for dealing with them.

(type your response here) what would you do? you are tutoring a group of 3 students. one is quite outgoing and begins to talk about a concert she attended last weekend. one student has been silent the whole session and another has started to work on homework for an entirely different class. use the space below to write a brief response about how you would bring the group back into focus:

types of difficult behavior the derailing student the passive student the dominating student the dominating student the confrontational student the hostile student the hostile student the anti-policy student click on each student to learn more

the derailing student let me tell you about my personal life! listen and validate your tutee’s feelings, but then draw the student’s attention back to the tutoring session. ask how the issue relates to the topic at hand. refocus attention by restating the relevant topic. use visual aids, hands-on activities, begin writing on the board, and involve the student. do a comprehension check by asking students to summarize what they understand.

the passive student i’m not sure why i’m even here… focus directly on the student from time to time change teaching strategies from group discussion to individually focused activities give strong positive reinforcement for any contribution acknowledge the feeling and relate to the tutee’s experience involve the student by directly asking him/her a question

the confrontational student that’s wrong! you should do it this way! acknowledge the student’s sentiments and recognize positive points. acknowledge that you and the student disagree. seek other students’ opinions. if they continue to argue, say: "i appreciate your comments, but i'd like to hear from others," or "it looks like we disagree." consult the assistant director or director.

the dominating student oh! i know that one! let me tell you! acknowledge the student’s comments, but give limited time, so others can express their views. say, "that's an interesting point, but let's see what other people think." make eye contact with another student and orient your body language towards him or her. meet with the student and explain the ground rules of tutoring.

the hostile student i hate the way you are teaching this! respond to the student’s fear. remain calm and polite and keep your own temper in check. rather than disagreeing with the student, build upon an agreed upon point. soften your body language, but keep eye contact. give the student space to calm down and even excuse his or herself from the situation. address the problem with the tutee alone.

the anti-policy student i’m not wrong! these rules aren’t fair! make policies visible. indicate parts of the policy the student is violating. reiterate that all people involved must be respectful to each other. remind students that drop-in sessions are 15-minutes long. minimize social conversation. refer student to the appropriate staff.

unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. unfortunately, i cannot help you with your specific homework problems, but, i will show you a similar problem so that you understand how to do it. that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! that’s the policy, and if you don’t like it, hire a private tutor! ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. ok, take out the homework and maybe we can do a few questions and see if you understand. what will you do? lac policy does not allow tutors to work on homework during a session. however, the student angrily states, “then what is the purpose of tutoring?” what would be the best response?

avoiding difficult behavior how do you set expectations for your tutoring sessions? tutors report that students are more responsible and cooperative when expectations are set clearly and firmly at the beginning of tutoring sessions, and are mutually agreed upon.

everyone must be on time. everyone must be on time. everyone must be on time. everyone must be on time. everyone must be on time. everyone must be on time. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must respect each other’s point of view. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must understand that tutoring is a collaborative event. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must come prepared for each session and not expect the tutor or other students to do their work. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. everyone must adhere to the center’s policies. what are your expectations? establishing expectations and setting ground rules for each tutoring session can help students be more responsible and cooperative during sessions. which of the following ground rules will you set for your tutees? select all that apply:

(type your response here) thought exercise even if you establish expectations and grounds rules, students may still have unrealistic expectations. if you give into these unrealistic expectations, why might this be detrimental for you, the learning assistance center and your colleagues?
addressing difficult behavior reflect reflect reflect reflect redirect redirect redirect redirect reinforce reinforce reinforce reinforce click on each approach to learn more

styles of addressing a problem click each option to view a strategy you can use to deal wit the situation click on a style to view each definition. assertive assertive assertive aggressive aggressive aggressive passive passive passive source: http://www.theoaktree.com/assrtquz.htm. how self-assertive are you? by donald a. cadogan, 1990.

assertiveness indicator i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i feel that people tend to take advantage of me. i tend to avoid confrontation. i tend to avoid confrontation. i tend to avoid confrontation. i tend to avoid confrontation. i tend to avoid confrontation. i tend to avoid confrontation. i am able to be assertive when necessary. i am able to be assertive when necessary. i am able to be assertive when necessary. i am able to be assertive when necessary. i am able to be assertive when necessary. i am able to be assertive when necessary. read the following statements and check the ones you feel are true about yourself:

types of assertions click each option to view a strategy you can use to deal wit the situation click on the types of assertions to learn about each type. basic basic basic empathetic empathetic empathetic i-language i-language i-language escalating escalating escalating

using escalating assertions problem 1 your tutee consistently arrives 10-15 minutes late for tutoring sessions. create 4 escalating assertion statements. click here to see one possible answer problem 2 your tutee consistently answers his or her ringing cell phone during your sessions. create 4 escalating assertion statements. click here to see one possible answer

possible answer to problem 2 tutee consistently answers ringing cell phone during sessions: 1st response: please refer to the tutee responsibility about cell phone use in the lac policy . 2nd response: remind the students that their use of the cell phone during the tutoring session will distract them and other students. 3rd response: firmly tell them that when they talk on the phone, it wastes your and other students’ time, as they have to wait until you get off the phone to continue. 4th response: give them a warning that they will have to step out of the lac if their phone continues to ring.

possible answer to problem 1 student consistently arrives late to tutoring sessions: 1st response: is this a good time to meet? would a different time be better for you? if so, please go to the front desk to re-apply for a time change. 2nd response: remind them that you have either other commitments after their appointment, or you have another student scheduled, so you cannot go over the time limit. 3rd response: i get frustrated when you are frequently late because it wastes our time. there are other students on the waiting list for tutoring. 4th response: give a warning to the student that you will have to drop him or her if the tardiness continues.

real scenarios from lac tutors anger & disrespect in the write room students being disrespectful to each other students being disrespectful to each other dealing with overly needy students dealing with overly needy students math anxiety math anxiety the problem professor the problem professor all or nothing expectations all or nothing expectations

anger & disrespect in the write room what would you do? click here to see a possible solution you need to fix the introduction and conclusion! i need an a on this paper! ugh! you are not helping! who is your boss!?

students being disrespectful to each other what would you do? click here to see a possible solution hey, stop. it’s my turn now. my assignment is more important, and it’s due tonight! you can get help when i’m finished.

what would you do? click here to see a possible solution i’m sorry, i still don’t get it. i’m just bad at math. i’ve always been bad. i don’t think there’s anything you can do to help me… math anxiety

what would you do? click here to see a possible solution you’re moving on to another student already? but i still need help! please, i need you to work with me! i need to pass this test! dealing with overly needy students

the problem professor what would you do? click here to see a possible solution my professor just ignores me in class! she never answers my questions. she doesn’t like me. it doesn’t matter what i do. i wish i had taken this class with someone else!
what’s the point of my being here if we’re not going to finish the assignment? all or nothing expectations what would you do? click here to see a possible solution

(type your response here) key takeaways throughout this presentation, you’ve learned about the types of difficult behaviors, strategies to avoid difficult behaviors, styles to address these behaviors when they happen and real scenarios that happened in the lac. use the space provided to jot down a few key points you plan to incorporate into your current tutoring practices:

summary when you notice unproductive behavior, address it by sending a clear message to the student that it is not acceptable. we are much more effective as tutors when we are centered and when we view our students with fondness rather than impatience. allow students to save face. when we put students down in front of others, other students will turn against us. your attitude will come across to your students, so it is important to maintain positivity. if, by chance, you feel that you have spoken sharply in an attempt to manage your students, own up to it and apologize to them.

thank you! thank you for viewing this presentation. we hope that you have gained a few key points and strategies for dealing with difficult student behavior that you can now apply to your role as a tutor in the lac. to check your knowledge and receive credit for viewing this presentation, please visit the following link and take the short google form assessment: google form assessment please take some time at the end of your assessment to evaluate this presentation. your feedback will help us design more effective and useful training for all tutors in the lac. thank you!
